Revision – Lesson 1 Conjunctions

Conjunctions are words that join two sentences, like 'and', 'or', 'because'.
Two types we studied:

  • Simple conjunctions: und (and), oder (or), aber (but). They do not change sentence structure.
    Example: Ich esse Brot und ich trinke Tee.
  • Verb movers: weil (because), obwohl (even though), wenn (if/when). They push the conjugating verb to the end in the second part of the sentence.
    Example: Ich esse Pizza weil ich Pizza liebe.

Indirect Speech – New Conjunctions

Now we learn 3 new conjunctions, used in indirect speech:

  • dass – that
  • ob – if/whether
  • W-Fragen – question words (wo, wann, warum, wie...).
All of these are verb pushers, meaning the conjugating verb moves to the end.

Examples with 'dass'

English: I think that German is easy.
German: Ich denke, dass Deutsch einfach ist.
Notice: ist moved to the end after 'dass'.

Without 'dass' it would have been: Deutsch ist einfach.

Examples with 'ob'

English: I want to ask whether German is easy.
German: Ich will fragen, ob Deutsch einfach ist.
'ist' moves to the end since 'ob' is a verb pusher.

Examples with W-Fragen

English: I want to ask where Kedar is.
German: Ich will fragen wo Kedar ist.
English: I want to know when she comes.
German: Ich will wissen wann sie kommt.
Note: W-question words stay the same, the verb moves to the end.

Summary

Simple conjunctions: und, oder, aber (no structure change).
Verb movers: weil, obwohl, wenn (move the verb to end).
Indirect speech conjunctions: dass (that), ob (if/whether), W-Fragen (wo, wann, warum, wie). These also push the verb to the end.

Golden Rule for verb pushers: 1) First sentence part remains same. 2) In second part, the conjugating verb goes to the end.
